ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Lots about different groups and how they are affected by media and political systems in their home countries.
I got better at Spanish and learned about witches, fake news, immigrants, and indigenous peoples.

I developed my reading, writing, and speaking skills in Spanish by exploring issues such as gender stereotypes/perceptions, indigenous worldviews and experiences, and how fake news affects experiences of immigration. I also developed skills in analyzing and discussing films and media of different types.
I improved a lot in my Spanish abilities including reading, writing, and speaking. It was interesting to study oppressed groups and being able to discuss the issues they face in Spanish.
You will definitely be pushed to speak in this class and articulate your thoughts on complicated topics.
Better understanding of Latin American history and social customs of the Spanish language.
I think I developed speaking and writing skills.
Developed my spanish speaking and writing
I developed my Spanish a lot, especially in writing.
This course really helped me learn how to talk about important social issues in the Spanish speaking world and also improved my confidence in speaking.
This is a great course to keep learning Spanish! You learn about indigenous people, witches, colonization, and much more.
I continued to develop my spanish speaking skills through speaking, writing and listening.
I learned a lot about indigenous culture, the history of women, and fake news.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: prof, partner engagement with this class. 
Weaknesses: my prof was fantastic but the overall course director was very scattered

A strength of this course is that there was a lot of room for discussion and practicing Spanish-speaking, writing, and reading. A big weakness is that it's asking us to discuss complicated and touchy topics in a language we half-understand, so a lot of the time we would resort to finishing the rest of our thought in English or just repeating "colonizacin es muy mal" a lot.

Strengths: High level of engagement thanks to several modalities of learning, frequent small homework assignments, and the necessity of active participation in class every day.
Weaknesses: At times, it was clear that the syllabus was formulated by a course coordinator other than the instructor. For example, if there was an unreasonable due date or policy for an assignment, this could not be easily remedied; the instructor could not take full responsibility because she did not set the policy in the first place. Also, it was sometimes unclear what the overall goals of the thematic units were (e.g. it would have been helpful to do some cumulative recap from the "brujas" unit to come away with some more concrete ideas rather than just specific analyses of works of art, etc.).

This course is strong in how it keeps consistent practice for learning the language throughout the semester. It can be improved by providing more opportunities to quiet students to practice their speaking.
The course is well structured, although the material can feel a bit repetitive at times.

Strengths: Profesora was very enthusiastic and supportive. Assignments were relevant and engaging.

Weaknesses: N/A

I really enjoyed being able to collaborate with different people. I think sometimes the topics that we were covering felt a little bit random, but I still enjoyed being able to cover a variety of subject areas. I also feel like it would have been nice to have a greater emphasis on grammar.
IT was very rigid and stuck by the syllabus strictly.

I think that the strengths are that it has a lot of collaboration, but one weakness is that the curriculum is very scattered and I didnt feel like we focused on improving our Spanish ability, just practicing what we already know how to do.

Strengths: well structured, interesting topics, great environment to learn the language
Weaknesses: the class felt very much like a high school class with a lot of busy work

This course demands your constant investment in outside of class work which did exercise my ability to read, speak, and write in spanish. However, in class, I felt like I was less compelled to participate because some of the content was opinionated and I didnt always feel my opinion was welcome or that I even had the capacity to explain my nuanced opinion in my limited vocabulary.
I thought that the content was very unique but varied a little too much.  If there were more related units, it would be easier to follow.  Overall, a great class!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! I felt like I learned a lot this semester and am studying abroad over the summer after taking this class.

I mean I guess. It's not really a choice for most people who are taking it. But for me my required L3 and L4 language classes at Yale weren't about the learning, but the friends I made along the way :)

Yes, this is a great intermediate Spanish course, especially as a first-year who had taken a significant amount of Spanish before coming to Yale but was not quite confident enough to place into L5. Be aware that this course meets in-person four mornings a week, so do not sign up for the 9:25 slot if you have a hard time waking up early every morning.
Yes, it is a great continuation in developing Spanish ability.
If you want to strengthen your speaking skills, sure. I would mostly use it as a vehicle to get to L5 or to complete your language requirement, though.
Yes!!!
I think I would recommend it if they want to just stay in practice with using Spanish.
If you have to take this class then yes.
I would recommend this class, I think it adds a lot of good experience without focus on grammar
Most people taking this course have to take it so I would recommend it if its required
Depends, if you want to be fluent in Spanish, no. But if you want to practice what you already know, yes.

Yes, I would if they were interested in Spanish.  It was a very engaging class that many of my classmates loved.  It taught me more about Spanish in the real world and forced me out of my Spanish comfort zone.
